item.title: Convergence of Cauchy Sequences in Metric Spaces
item.description: Definition Let $\left\{ p_{n} \right\}$ be a sequence of points in a metric space $(X,d)$. If for every positive number $\varepsilon$, there exists a positive number $N$ such that $$ n\ge N,\ m\ge N \implies d(p_{n},p_{m})<\varepsilon $$ is satisfied, then $\left\{ p_{n} \right\}$ is called a Cauchy sequence. If every Cauchy sequence in a metric space $X$ converges to a point in $X$, then $X$ is called a complete space.

item.title: Polish Space
item.description: Definition A topological space $X$ is called a Polish space if it satisfies the following conditions: (i): $X$ is a metrizable space. (ii): $X$ is a separable space. (iii): $X$ is a complete space. Explanation The term Polish Space directly comes from ‘Poland’, as you might guess from the naturalized expression. The reason behind this naming is that this concept was first actively researched by topologists and logicians from Poland.

item.title: Balls and Open Sets, Closed Sets in Metric Spaces
item.description: Definition Given a metric space where $\left( X, d \right)$, let $a \in X$ and $r > 0$.
